channel.title: {antisnare.} [Label]
channel.description:
along side with @foryou's label "vvvvv", I made a label that is around the exact same style as vvvvv except it also promotes other tracks from other people named antisnare.
also it's affiliated with vvvvv as well so that's cool
discord: https://discord.gg/24tMSb5 soundcloud: https://soundcloud.com/antisnare youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCcXRxbNfGu9nVTtgVuAjz7Q
also, antisnare. releases stuff commercially as well so if you want your stuff to be released under antisnare., come right ahead

item.title: {antisnare.} [Label]
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
It could work if the first couple of label releases were label samplers - effectively a ‘Various Artists’ release released under the label name.

You can also create multiple accounts using a different email address for each.

Bit of a p.i.t.a. to keep logging out/in (Hello SoundCloud), but doable.

 
[Edit…

Seems they’re adding support for multiple artists per account “very soon”

Amuse.io FAQ: Can I handle more than one artist in one account? (2 Aug 2018)

You can’t today, but you will very soon. We are adding more services with every new version of the app and in the near future, you will be able to choose from multiple artists in one account.

In the meantime, you could log in with a Facebook account and different Gmail-accounts to create a multiple Amuse account.

Read full topic

item.title: {antisnare.} [Label]
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
I guess the label thing is just a bit of fun - which is fine.

Still, as Blakkaz said, cool name.

If you ever get serious about it, is the intention that it will have a certain sound as a label - i.e. have artists of a certain style or genre?

When I saw the name, I thought it work well for a dark IDM label.

Read full topic

item.title: {antisnare.} [Label]
item.dc:creator: Polar
item.description:
I guess I worded that wrong, because it isn’t expensive at all, it’s just hard for someone just starting a label to be comfortable with spending $80.

I just got the single artist plan a few days ago because I needed it for a label release, I’m pretty impressed how cheap it is.

Read full topic

item.title: {antisnare.} [Label]
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Another upside to Distrokid is that you can specify the royalties split directly in your account. Distrokid then routes the relevant percentages to the right contributors.

 

Polar:

It’ll still be costly for a label, but not as much at least.

Awww, come on.
It’s not even close to “costly” for anyone who’s even remotely serious about starting a label.

The single artist package is $20/year for unlimited releases.

The 2-artist package is $36/year. That’s not a killer price to be able to release unlimited tracks and albums from two artists.
(They’ll even throw in a third artist if you handle it right.)

The 5+ artist package is $80/year.

Even without the extra discount, those prices should be more than acceptable to anyone even remotely serious about being a ‘label’.

It repeatedly blows my mind that people here have plans to make their music something more serious, but aren’t willing to put any real investment into it.

Makes me wonder what kind of label it could be when the owner can’t do what it takes to scrape together $36-80 each year.

It’s as though the idea of getting some paid work to fund your ambitions until they can pay for themselves is an alien concept.

Why would anyone release a track on a label that thinks $36/year is ‘costly’?

Read full topic

item.title: {antisnare.} [Label]
item.dc:creator: Polar
item.description:
If you make an account on distrokid, and logout before buying anything, wait 96 hours and you’ll get an email with a 40% off code. It’ll still be costly for a label, but not as much at least.

Amuse only lets you release as one artist, and as a label, you’ll release as multiple albums.

item.description:

In the event I get 4700000 plays, I’d want to know how the royalties were being handled.
Just food for thought.
